body: Originally introduced in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1524

I think these threads are also related:
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17265002/hadoop-no-filesystem-for-scheme-file
- http://grokbase.com/t/cloudera/scm-users/1288xszz7r/no-filesystem-for-scheme-hdfs
What is the path of reconciliation if the commit fails? How is a commit failure indicated?
@drcrallen Commit failure of what kind indicated to who?

@gianm Right now any sort of error in the commit results in complete failure of the persist. I think I'm mis-interpreting the purpose of this PR.

Is it possible to split up the PR more?

At a cursory glance it might be able to be split into:
1. IndexTask.convertTuningConfig changes 
2. Removing Indexer
3. Moving time and row persisting
4. Moving getSink to private
5. Moving to Committer interface
@drcrallen This PR is relatively small and I think there is a decent description of the scope of changes. Why do we need to split into 5 different PRs?

@fjy Because there's a lot of concepts in one PR, even thought the line count is small.

There seem to be code maintenance changes, responsibility changes (who handles time and row related persisting), and API version-ish changes (migrating from Runnable to Committer from Firehosev2)
And they are done in a "will affect everybody (who uses plumber/indexing stuff)" kind of manner.

@drcrallen ah that was just an artifact of us working on the 0.8.1-rc branch. Fixed the pom versions and everything should be happy again.

Extends build time by 30s on my local box. 

Seems to work well, and the packaging mechanism is some crazy maven-foo.

`run_druid_server.sh` is not documented though. So that should probably be added at some point.

Looks good to me :+1: (waiting for Travis)

In general, on its own, this PR looks OK to me but I have following general comments.
1) It has definite merge conflicts with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1609 , is it possible to base the work on top of that PR (may be merge that one). I have incorporated review comments, by adding code comments, to what was last discussed in the dev sync-up meeting. That would save me some work.

2) Without seeing a PR that includes a firechiefy driver that drives a plumber on top of Appenderator ... it is very hard to imagine how this is really going to work all the way to provide the results we are trying to achieve. That PR could just be bare minimum code (not necessarily working version and may contain lots of TODOs) that shows the essentials.

I would really like to at least get 1st done before this PR is merged.
LGTM
LGTM
LGTM

So I've gone back to the way I initially had it, with the taskResource logic pushed up into AbstractFixedIntervalTask - doing so allows for the passed id value to be reused for groupId and for generating a new taskResource if passed as null.
Close and reopen to restart the build.

That shouldn't be an issue. The filter is applied _FIRST_. This is the reason there are dimension extraction stuff for both the dimension specification AND filters, which must both be set. Specifying a dimension extraction in the dimension specification, then making a "normal" dimension selector on  the extracted dimension will NOT work.

You can see the filter being applied at
io.druid.query.groupby.GroupByQueryEngine#process

``` java
    final Sequence<Cursor> cursors = storageAdapter.makeCursors(
        Filters.convertDimensionFilters(query.getDimFilter()),
        intervals.get(0),
        query.getGranularity()
    );
```

where `storageAdapter` comes from the incremental index created by the sub query, and `query.getDimFilter()` _should_ be the filter you were mentioning.

That neither proves nor disproves this issue. A unit test should be able to reveal if there is an issue here.

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/druid-development/tier/druid-development/1I3CmxlOipM/e3-SpWqG170J could fit here also?

That directly applies to 5, 2 (and maybe 6?) on the list.

@guobingkun it looks like your `tar` command does not support file names longer than 100 characters. I have a fix that might help in your case. Can you try this https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1644

This issue also exists when using the Druid Tranquility library (https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility).

> Tranquility works with the Druid indexing service (http://druid.io/docs/latest/Indexing-Service.html). To get started, you'll need an Overlord, enough Middle Managers for your realtime workload, and enough Historical nodes to receive handoffs. You don't need any Realtime nodes, since Tranquility uses the indexing service for all of its ingestion needs.

After running `mvn -DskipTests clean package` locally.
@xvrl I tried `Apache Maven 3.3.1 (cab6659f9874fa96462afef40fcf6bc033d58c1c; 2015-03-13T20:10:27+00:00)` but still gave the same error.

improvement is great. But, if I am reading it right then, now that ObjectResourceHolder itself is recycled, it will not in general be GC'd and hence finalize() is not called and warning about "Not Closed" is never printed if client code forgets to call close and that can potentially cause memory leak.
At one point I was tempted to change this but I remember @cheddar had very strong opinion about it.
@himanshug that's a good point. Is the finalize just a memory leak tool then? to find out who takes resources and doesn't release them?

yes, i think so.
BTW, if the change in this PR is acceptable then I think we can remove that finalize() as well because it will not be serving any purpose anymore and if there is not a strong reason then one should in general avoid overriding finalize() for all sorts of reasons.

So, from what @himanshug found in the past, the mere existence of the `finalize()` causes significant increased cost in creating the object.

It does exist there for memory leak protection and has caught memory leaks in the past.  Memory leaks of this kinda are pretty gnarly and I'm still very wary of removing this check.  As I said on the previous "improve stupid pool perf" PR, I believe that the speed of `StupidPool` is a symptom and the actual problem is that the ObjectStrategy objects are checking one of these out every time it needs to decompress something.  A better fix, in my mind, would be to restructure it so that a single buffer is checked out for each column and that reference is re-used as long as that column is in use.

@guobingkun it looks like you might be running into https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MASSEMBLY-677
Do you have a custom maven repository setup with mirrors? Does it work if you remove any repository customizations in your maven settings.xml, to have it default to maven central?

@xvrl that would be a problem. we have corp level maven mirror that contains public maven + internal stuff. All the machines get a [internally certified]wrapped version of maven that uses those mirrors. It is not possible to change things inside settings.xml in most cases and this will continue to fail build for us.

My successful workaround to Druid 0.8.0 by patching the **druid-hdfs-storage** extension:
- Git Clone Druid from https://github.com/druid-io/druid.git and check out tag "druid-0.8.0".
- Update the pom.xml dependency scopes of artifacts "hadoop-hdfs", "hadoop-common" and "hadoop-hdfs" from "test" to "provided".

```
         <dependency>
           <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
           <artifactId>hadoop-hdfs</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
           <classifier>tests</classifier>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
         <dependency>
           <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
           <artifactId>hadoop-common</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
           <classifier>tests</classifier>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
         <dependency>
           <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
           <artifactId>hadoop-hdfs</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
```
- Update HdfsStorageDruidModule.java with patch mentioned in this thread.

```
 public class HdfsStorageDruidModule implements DruidModule
@@ -82,6 +86,10 @@ public class HdfsStorageDruidModule implements DruidModule

     final Configuration conf = new Configuration();

+    // Walk around a typical case that "maven-assembly" causes bug about "No FileSystem for scheme: hdfs" while loading hadoop-hdfs dependency
+    conf.set("fs.hdfs.impl", DistributedFileSystem.class.getName());
+    conf.set("fs.file.impl", LocalFileSystem.class.getName());
+
     // Set explicit CL. Otherwise it'll try to use thread context CL, which may not have all of our dependencies.
     conf.setClassLoader(getClass().getClassLoader());
```
- Do a maven clean and install ("mvn clean install").
-  Zip the patched Druid extension (.m2\repository\io\druid\extensions\druid-hdfs-storage -> druid-hdfs-storage.zip).
- Copy the patched Druid extension on the Druid host.

```
ls -al ~/.m2/repository/io/druid/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/
cp druid-hdfs-storage.zip ~/.m2/repository/io/druid/extensions/
rm -rf ~/.m2/repository/io/druid/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/
cd ~/.m2/repository/io/druid/extensions/
unzip druid-hdfs-storage.zip
```
- Launch Druid

**Full patch contents: patch.diff**

```
diff --git a/extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml b/extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml
index 9518404..7ad60dc 100644
--- a/extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml
+++ b/extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml
@@ -81,20 +81,20 @@
           <artifactId>hadoop-hdfs</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
           <classifier>tests</classifier>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
         <dependency>
           <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
           <artifactId>hadoop-common</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
           <classifier>tests</classifier>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
         <dependency>
           <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
           <artifactId>hadoop-hdfs</artifactId>
           <version>2.3.0</version>
-          <scope>test</scope>
+          <scope>provided</scope>
         </dependency>
       </dependencies>

diff --git a/extensions/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/storage/hdfs/HdfsStorageDruidModule.java b/extensions/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/storage/hdfs/HdfsStorageDruidModule.java
index 52eadd3..94b63fe 100644
--- a/extensions/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/storage/hdfs/HdfsStorageDruidModule.java
+++ b/extensions/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/storage/hdfs/HdfsStorageDruidModule.java
@@ -29,6 +29,8 @@ import io.druid.initialization.DruidModule;
 import io.druid.storage.hdfs.tasklog.HdfsTaskLogs;
 import io.druid.storage.hdfs.tasklog.HdfsTaskLogsConfig;
 import org.apache.hadoop.conf.Configuration;
+import org.apache.hadoop.fs.LocalFileSystem;
+import org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DistributedFileSystem;

 import java.util.List;
 import java.util.Properties;
@@ -82,6 +84,10 @@ public class HdfsStorageDruidModule implements DruidModule

     final Configuration conf = new Configuration();

+    // Walk around a typical case that "maven-assembly" causes bug about "No FileSystem for scheme: hdfs" while loading hadoop-hdfs dependency
+    conf.set("fs.hdfs.impl", DistributedFileSystem.class.getName());
+    conf.set("fs.file.impl", LocalFileSystem.class.getName());
+
     // Set explicit CL. Otherwise it'll try to use thread context CL, which may not have all of our dependencies.
     conf.setClassLoader(getClass().getClassLoader());

```

@himanshug @guobingkun I can try disabling embedding the maven metadata into the local maven repo and see if that still works. If not, I suggest we make the tarball assembly optional as part of a separate release profile that we can activate when needed to make the release. Would that work?
@xvrl if it works by disabling the maven metadata, good or else making it optional sounds good to me as most people dont need to build that.
@xvrl updated code to handle all kinds of glob paths, added unit tests and updated the "integration test" as well

:+1: without further changes. some comments though,
- Would be nice to have a deserialization test for the config.
- spymemcached docs say Retry means "Continue to retry a failing node until it comes back up." This seems like behavior you wouldn't want for the query cache- ideally, if memcache dies, queries keep on chugging as best they can without the cache. Blocking and waiting for the cache to come back seems less good.
@gianm I was under the impression that such retries still obey the timeout though.

If the timeout is long, that's still a bummer, since it means a downed cache node will inject $CACHE_TIMEOUT latency into every segment scan. To avoid that you need to be able to fail-fast on a downed cache node.

Finagle has a good strategy for dealing with that kind of thing: https://twitter.github.io/finagle/guide/Clients.html#client-fail-fast
:+1: Agree with Gian's comments though. Free feel to merge after they are addressed.

@fjy / @gianm I don't think we have good tests for `JsonConfigProvider` stuff. Are you just looking for general deserialization through any means? or are you specifically wanting something that tests JsonConfigProvider?

@drcrallen I just saw the deserialization of a property into an enum, and the thoughts crossed my mind: I wonder if that works? I wonder if it's case sensitive? So then I thought a test would be cool.

I think a test to make sure Jackson can deserialize some json into this object would be good enough. If that works then I'd be pretty confident that the JsonConfigProvider step will work too.

@fjy  It should be mostly backward compatible except that we deprecated `druid.extensions.coordiantes`, ``druid.extensions.remoteRepositories`, `druid.extensions.localRepository` and `druid.extensions.defaultVersion`. At runtime, Druid loads extensions and hadoop dependencies from local file system instead of internet.

there are few issues with this PR. 
closing, until fixed.

@nishantmonu51 

Serialization speed is probably affected by API choices. Roaring itself serializes to a DataOutput, but we then have to convert this serialization to an in-memory byte array. By allowing bitmap serialization directly to an output stream, we would gain speed (a bit) and reduce memory usage.
@himanshug does this need to go into 0.8.11? please add to milestone if so.

@xvrl yes it is a fix for regression, it has to go in 0.8.1
@gianm thanks for updating the milestone.
@xvrl yes it does, it fixes a regression from 0.8.0. I added the milestone
@qix can you also sign the CLA here: http://druid.io/community/cla.html
:+1: I'm happy this finally got fixed :D

The `"value":0` here means that nothing actually failed (it's a count of failures):

``` json
{"feed":"metrics","timestamp":"2015-08-25T10:46:50.498Z","service":"realtime","host":"localhost:8085","metric":"ingest/handoff/failed","value":0,"dataSource":"wikipedia"}
```
@gianm sounds good, can we put your useful PR comments somewhere in the code?

@xvrl what/where were you thinking of adding? I did add a "word of warning" section about splitting up large segment sets. I didn't add anything about allowOlderVersions, since the lighter more useful constraint is still enforced (your version must be <= the lock version rather than == the lock version).
@xvrl thanks for creating the PR for backport.
Cool, squash and I'm :+1:
